title: Advanced Diploma in Intellectual Property Rights and Competition Law
headline: Learn about the principles and laws related to Intellectual Property Right and Competition law in this free course.
description: This free online course will introduce you to the ever evolving technology driven aspect of intellectual property rights (IPRs) and competition law. The course describes the conflict between the domain of IPRs and competition law. This course explains the general principles and laws related to Intellectual Property Right and Competition law. The course also provides an overview of the application of both laws in different jurisdictions.

courseDescription:
This course introduces you to the concept and meaning of intellectual property and how it is important for socio-economic progress. The course explains how for so many years, trademarks have been used as a unique way of identifying a product or service to distinguish it from its competitors. The course takes a historical look into how great inventors were able to get patents for their inventions many years ago. You will learn about the adoption of competition law by countries around the world.

The course explains in detail the basic objective of the competition law, and how it is used to encourage the free and open process of competition. You will learn about anti-competitive agreement, how some companies negatively use it in fixing prices and dividing the market which has the effect of reducing competition in their market. You will also learn how intellectual property and competition policy are put in place to prevent anticompetitiveness and ensure the presence of a competitive market that generates economic efficiency and welfare.

The course also explains how copyright owners sometimes abuse their dominant position by way of implementing policies capable of eliminating their competitors.  The course then gives several instances where competition laws were violated and how an international court like the European court of justice was able to resolve disputes arising from the violations of competition laws. You will learn about the methods used by trademark owners to protect the reputation and image of their brand especially with respect to  their luxury brands. 

 

Start Course Now
certificateDetail:
All Alison courses are free to enrol study and complete. To successfully complete this diploma course and become an Alison Graduate, you need to achieve 80% or higher in each course assessment. Once you have completed this diploma course, you have the option to acquire an official Diploma, which is a great way to share your achievement with the world.

Your Alison diploma is:
  • Ideal for sharing with potential employers
  • Include it in your CV, professional social media profiles and job applications.
  • An indication of your commitment to continuously learn, upskill & achieve high results.
  • An incentive for you to continue empowering yourself through lifelong learning.
Alison offers 3 types of Diplomas for completed Diploma courses:
  • Digital diploma: a downloadable diploma in PDF format immediately available to you when you complete your purchase.
  • diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security-marked diploma, posted to you with FREE shipping.
  • Framed diploma: a physical version of your officially branded and security marked diploma in a stylish frame, posted to you with FREE shipping.
Start Course Now

All diploma are available to purchase through the Alison Shop. For more information on purchasing Alison diploma, please visit our FAQs. If you decide not to purchase your Alison diploma, you can still demonstrate your achievement by sharing your Learner Record or Learner Achievement Verification, both of which are accessible from your Dashboard. For more details on our diploma pricing, please visit our Pricing Page

modules.name: Module
modules.details: Anticompetitive agreement and abuse of dominance in Intellectual Property Right Protection
modules.description: In this module, you will learn about abusive practices by dominant enterprises related to patent. You will learn about licensing regulations regarding copyright, and how the practices can lead to abusive practices by the property right holder. You will also learn about the main objectives of intellectual property and competition law across India, Europe and America.

slides:
• Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain the concept of intellectual property including concept such as the creation of the human mind, incentive for innovation, statutory right for a limited period of time for disclosing invention, and fruits of creativity
    • Discuss the basic principles of trademarks in intellectual property
    •  Identify the uniqueness of a trademark and how it distinguishes a product from its competitors
    • Discuss how geographical indications are used in identifying goods as agricultural, natural goods manufactured in the in the territory of a country
    • Describe the importance of copyright as an important aspect of rights in intellectual property
    • Describe how a product works or operates, and how it is protected by patent law
    • Explain how materials are used in electronic hardware and how they are protected such that other companies do not use them
    • Define trade secrets and explain how it has helped many organizations like CocaCola become successful
    • List the the advantages and disadvantages of trade secrets

  • Lesson Summary 
    • The WTO's agreement on trade related aspects of intellectual property rights (TRIPS) attempts to strike a balance between the long term social objective of providing incentives for future inventions and creations, and the short term objective of allowing people to use existing inventions and creations
    • Intellectual property results from the application of someone's mind or intellect to create something new or original
    • The creative activity culminating in intellectual property is necessary for socio-economic progress 
    • Intellectual property rights grant monopoly to ensure rewards
    • Material incentives and rewards encourage greater creative activity
    • Thomas Alva Edison had 389 patents on lamp and electrical power, 189 on phonograph, 150 on telegraph, 141 on battery, and 34 on telephone
    • Trademark is a unique way of identifying a product or service to distinguish it from its competitors 
    • A trademark can comprise letters, words, numbers, colours, sound, smell, logo, shape, picture, aspect of packaging or any other combination of these
    • Kinds of trademarks include: Marks on goods, Service marks, Certification trademarks, Collective marks, Well known marks, Trade names
    • Copyrights provide free and automatic protection for an author's original expression of ideas and information captured in a specific medium
  • Lesson Summary

  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Explain the meaning of abuse of dominance in the concept of competition law
    • List the various forms of abuse, and the act on abuse of dominant position
    • Explain business combinations and the procedure for investigating combinations
    • Discuss the appreciable and adverse effect of combination on competition in India
    • Describe the concept of competition law, the components of the law and the application of the law
    • Describe the development of competition law in India
    • Distinguish between horizontal agreements and vertical agreements
    • Explain the India competition act and anti competitive practices
    • Define bid rigging as it relates to competitiveness
    • Discuss the different categories of agreements and the accepted regulations for agreements

  • Lesson Summary
    • Strigler in 1998 defined competition as as a rivalry between individuals (or group of nations) which arises whenever tow or more parties strive for something that all cannot obtain 
    • Adam Smith in his book, Wealth of Nations said "People of the same trade seldom meet together, even for merriment and diversion, the conversation ends in conspiracy agains the public or some contrivance to raise prices
    • Article 101 of the Treaty (81 Original) prohibits agreement between two independent market operators which restrict competition
    • In recent years, that has been a "quiet revolution" in the adoption of competition law by countries around the world
    • Markets may fail for a number of reasons, with anti-competitive practices, including collusion and the abuse of market dominance being common and important courses
    • The basic objective of the competition law is to encourage the process of competition
    • Policies can distort market and competitive process 
    • An anti-competitive agreement is where two or more companies operating as competitors in the same market agree to cooperate in fixing prices and dividing the market which has the effect of reducing competition in their market 
  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Describe the concept of ownership of rights of intellectual property and the social values of protecting intellectual property
    • Explain the trade offs between competition and innovation
    • Differentiate between complementary and supplementary relationship in intellectual property and competition law
    • Describe the dangers of having too much or too little intellectual property
    • List the objectives of intellectual property
    • Explain the  Sherman act of 1890 passed in response to growing fear of the enormous accumulation capital and trust due to the industrial age
    • Explain several anti trust laws in the United states federal economic regulatory scheme
    • Describe the various interfaces between intellectual property and competition law

  • Lesson Summary
    • Intellectual property and competition policy share a common objective which is to protect competitive market so that they generate economic efficiency and welfare
    • There is no clear trade off between competition and innovation, and therefore the two policies must not be seen as contradictory
    • The "property right" nature of intellectual property seems to play an important role in building an argument for a strong protection of intellectual property rights 
    • There are three types of ownership: communal, private and state ownership
    • When an open access resource becomes scarce, individuals lack the incentive to conserve it because they cannot capture the full gains from doing so
    • Intellectual property law creates property rights on information if the social value of this information exceeds the cost of development 
    • Valuation is essentially the bringing together of the economic concept of value and the legal concept of property
    • The need to allow property owner to capture in full the returns of his / her investment and to avoid free riding is generally emphasized as one of the main justifications for instituting property rights 
    • Intellectual property allows consumers to make choices between competing entrepreneurs with the goods and services they provide 
    • The interface between intellectual property rights and competition law may lead to two distinct result
  • Learning Outcomes 
  • Upon successful completion of this module, you will be able to:
    • Describe how companies monopolize service markets, and how the competition law addresses this
    • Describe the challenges faced by tying product with service
    • Explain the essential facilities doctrine
    • Discuss about the price fixing by the cartels
    • Describe the effects of patent pools and price fixing
    • Describe the effect of market allocation on competition in the market
    • Discuss how patent owners are using their intellectual property to control the geographical market
    • Describe trade secrets and how distributors or manufacturers approach contract restrains
    • Discuss about vertical restraints that have existed for so many years
    • Describe the roles of the various agencies saddled with the responsibility of enforcing the anti trust laws

  • Lesson Summary 
    • Market power is the ability profitably to maintain prove above or output below competitive levels for a significant period of time 
    • Agencies will not presume that a patent, copyright, or trade or secret necessarily confers market power upon its owner
    • In the anti-trust context, market power could be illegally acquired or maintained or even lawfully acquired and maintained 
    • Kodak used its monopoly over photocopier and micrographic parts to attempt to create and a second monopoly over the service markets 
    • Intergraph is an OEM manufacturer with Intel microprocessors 
    • A cartel is said to exist when two or more enterprises enter into an explicit or implicit agreement to fix prices to limit production and supply, to allocate market share or sales quota, or to engage in collusive bidding or bid rigging in one or more markets 
    • When a group of competitors enters into a series of separate but similar agreements with competitors or others, a strong inference arise that such agreements are the result of concerted actions 
    • Agreements or combinations between dealers, having for their sole purpose the destruction of competition and fixing of prices are injurious to the public
